The bars are trying to be "exclusive" by limiting people and creating fake lines to get in. If you are a hotel guest you can get on the list, but have to be in the bars by 10pm. I saw at least 5 different arguments between doormen and want to be patrons because they were not being let in and had to wait in a line even though the bars were not crowded. One lady was an owner of one of the units and was not let into the pool. She got the manager and was finally let in. The drinks are really expensive at $10 a piece, which is way above other area bars. A friend of our tried to get in but the doorman said he could not go to the bar unless he was willing to do table service, which costs at least $300. We were in the bar and there was no table service going on at that time. The people in the bars are wantabe posers, and like to act like they have money. Although I thought it was good for people watching. The pool area is really small but the bar by the pool has alot of plush seating and has a good vibe, even though most people are trying to pose. Get down there early to get a seat, otherwise there will not be any. Parking is $30 which is high, and you have everything is expensive in the hotel. We saw at least 5 different bachelor/bachelorette parties going on at the hotel. This place would be good for that. Overall, the rooms and common areas are nice and modern and have a hip vibe. It was fine for a night but I thought too expensive for more than that for what you get.

Reviews.Title: “Too old to be young, too young to be a sad old rocker”
Reviews.Author: soulmates63
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hard Rock Hotel, because my husband was going to a conference at the Hotel. As we walked in, the rock vibe resounded off every pillar and wall, ceiling and floor surface - it was going to be a noisy stay. The staff were very attentive, if a little too cool. The room was actually amazing. Really comfortable - it was all very new so was lovely and clean and fresh. The bed was very comfortable to lie in - but the corners of the base were keen to catch your shins and ankles and we ended up with very fashionable black and blue legs. The bathroom and loo were very spacious, but had glass doors, and although that can be quite seductive for the shower, a little more privacy for the toilet would have made it more comfortable. We had a living area and a bedroom area with two very large televisions. We had a nice balcony which meant we could easily have some fresh air as well as aircon. The only gripe really was the other guests - they seemed to party all night and didn't seem keen to close their bedroom doors, so the noise travelled! I began to sound like a very grouchy head teacher.

Reviews.Title: “It does smell like rotten eggs”
Reviews.Author: misledgeekboy
Reviews.Content: I agree with the other person, there is a smell of rotten eggs in some of the rooms. Another person that I know is staying here and said exactly the same thing, So if your lucky, you won't get one of the rooms with a ventilation problem, and if your unlucky like my friends and myself and can't change rooms, then you live with the bathroom a bit smelly...

Reviews.Title: “Ideal”
Reviews.Author: joletr
Reviews.Content: This is a great hotel. It's in a fun area with lots of people out for a good time. It's not a golf resort. It's not a caribean resort. I have no idea what the people who have given poor reviews expected. It's a great hotel in the best area of the city. It's modern and hip and you can't go wrong. The pool is amazing as are the clubs and dining. You can't please everyone unfortunately.

Reviews.Title: “uber-cool”
Reviews.Author: Robwash
Reviews.Content: Have stayed twice for the weekend for a quick getaway. We live in Los Angeles. Have stayed at several of the other hotels in the area, the Solamar and Hilton being the best of them. First, the negatives: $30 per day valet fee (ouch). They do warn you though and there is a lot between the hotel and the ballpark which is a lot cheaper. Can be noisy in the halls at night. Quite a few private parties with beautiful young and drunk people in some of the rooms. Rooms were clean but housekeeping was erratic. Still not sure if there was an actual turndown service. Phantom extra charges for reasons that weren't clear. I was afraid to even breathe around the mini-bar. And if you like uncomfortable modern furniture, you'll love this place. Wear ankle pads...trust me. The positives: THE best location. Great bars. Nobu right in the hotel. A buzz in the lobby and all around and within the hotel that lets you know this is the epicenter of the Gaslamp quarter. You will smile when you walk in. Super-friendly , young, attractive, and energetic staff. Exciting place to stay. The bottom line: The hotel offers an experience. If you feel like doing "trendy", this is your best bet. The Solamar is more refined with a somewhat more mature clientele. But it is also slightly less "hip". The "W" has a mediocre location for a short stay. If you want the great location without the pizazz, try the Hilton. Otherwise, the Hard Rock is a fun alternative. Gratuitous tips: book Nobu BEFORE you arrive. Lots of great steak houses. Donovan's is the best, the Palm the worst. There is a new Zagets guide for San Diego. Stay the heck on our side of the border. Check out the bleachers at PetCo field if their isn't a game. It's a park open to the public. Carry a little pop-up map. Have a Mojito at lunch; you will ahve a better time.

Reviews.Title: “Best Place I have Stayed at in San Diego”
Reviews.Author: Reddog5150
Reviews.Content: After our second stay, I feel safe saying that this is the place to stay in San Diego. I love the location and the rooms. This time we had a view of the city skyline and the pool. We had breakfast via room service and it was great and fast. The hotel is still getting up and running, but I think it already beats any other choice for a great hotel in San Diego. The location cannot be beat. We left the hotel a few times to take in the gaslamp district and we were always within a minute or two of our room. I am looking forward to the Summer pool scene and walking next door to Petco park. FYI, the trolley stops right outside the front door. This was perfect when we went to lunch in old town.

Reviews.Title: “Cool but LOUD”
Reviews.Author: travelsmith505
Reviews.Content: The hotel itself was overall pretty cool, and in a great location. The shower was nice and the beds were comfortable, but the place was a zoo on a Saturday night, and not exactly what I wanted to deal with. If you want to be up clubbing all night then it's a cool place to stay. BUT, if you thought that maybe you could come home at 1am and get some sleep, think again. The club on the 4th floor roof pumps out music so loud that we felt like we were in the club from our 11th floor room. I assumed that the place would have a lot going on, but not THAT much. We also had to push our way past a bunch of people just to get to the front door, and then show the bouncers our room key just to get in the building. So I'm guessing this is supposed to make us feel cool that we got in? Not sure... I'm not at all insulting Hard Rock because they've got a great brand and they are doing a good job of keeping up their image. I just wanted to pass along the details in case someone else was interested in a relaxing vacation. FYI...The valet service is $30 for guests, and you have to pay a mandatory $15 a night for a bottle of water, some candy, phone calls and internet services (which should be optional in my opinion).

Reviews.Title: “Rock and Roll Hangover”
Reviews.Author: MonkeysGirl
Reviews.Content: It pains me to give as harsh of a criticism as I am about to give to such a beautifully designed hotel, but I can't in good conscience stay silent. To get a feel for the place imagine a 4 Seasons hotel that has been commercialized to be a cheap and annoying version of something like Applebee's. It is like Britney Spears wrote the customer service training manual and hired the staff just after John Lennon or Jim Morrison signed off on the establishment. The staff are young, hip, good looking people who seem to be more preoccupied with looking cool than running a hotel. Our very first taste of things to come began as we got out at the valet entrance of the hotel. The valets were clearly not interested in listening to what the customer needed as much as they wanted to herd you through the line like cattle. Not completely out of the ordinary, but it became a problem later when we got to the room and find our luggage missing some items that we told the baggage handler's to bring up in the first place. The lobby is very loud which makes it difficult to hear. The receptionist asked what music we wanted four times, A minor issue considering the larger ones I will discuss, but even after asking four different times through the noise in the lobby our music in the room was still wrong. When we got upstairs we were impressed by the room's beautiful design, view, and quality furnishings. Our room featured a massive wall mounted LCD flat screen television complete with interactive menu and internet connectivity provided by a remote control keypad. The minute we turned the TV on, the music was gone for good not to return because we couldn't figure out how to get it back. It should be noted that if you are not the most technically inclined of people the rooms multimedia gadgets are difficult to manuver. There was no ethernet cable available in the room as advertised, so we were unable to access the internet from our computer, forcing us to use the internet via the tv. The keypad remote used to surf the internet did not work very well and we were forced to abandoned our cause. Unfortunately, our television would not work after that and maintenance had to be called to fix the problem. The repairman was perplexed with what to do to fix the issue, and we waited with him for about 45 minutes in a small room thinking of what we should do with ourselves in the meantime. Once he figured it out we thanked him and decided it would be best not to use the internet again which was sad because we paid something like $15.99 for the service we could no longer use. As a personal opinion perhaps not shared by others, it has always bothered me for a really nice pricey hotel to charge for internet service. It feels like I am being nickeled and dimed. About the time we were saying goodbye to our repairman we realized that some of our bags were missing. This is when I discovered that the bellman did not listen when I said please bring all of mine and my wife's bags to the room. I immediately went down to see where the breakdown was stopping at the valet desk to discuss the problem. The valet apologized and said he would correct the problem. I waited to see what the results would be for about 15 minutes. When nothing happened I asked what the problem was. The valet began asking me about the color and make of my vehicle. He apologized and said that his staff couldn't find the car. Realizing of course, he could do nothing for me and perhaps wanting to dodge the bullet, turned me over to the manager who behaved as if I was bothering him. He was impatient and somewhat inconsiderate of my problem. He never even once apologized for what had happened. Instead he opted to have me go down with him to search for the vehicle. Once we found the vehicle he told me to stay put, he ran away to go and search for the keys leaving me down in a garage I had no idea how to get out of. I found the exit and the valet floor boss no sooner than the manager arrived to tell me his people lost the keys and that the Hard Rock would gladly be picking up the parking fees. About ten minutes later the manager found the keys and had the vehicle into the queue because he thought I needed it. I just needed the bags. The car waited in the valet queue upstairs in the rain for approximately 20 minutes without my knowledge before I asked what was taking so long to get my bags and looking around the corner to see if they had brought the car up instead of bringing the bags. Sadly I was right and the bags were in the car still waiting in the valet line. Once I saw this I told the valet to bring the remainder of the bags up now. I went upstairs and my wife asked why I didn't bring the bags up myself and I alluded that we could trust the valet's at the hotel to do that. I was wrong and after a 20 minute conversation with my wife I found myself going back downstairs to find the bags sitting unattended in the lobby. I had to find someone to get the bags and follow me upstairs. After we had all of our things upstairs it was time to use the shower. The shower in the bathroom is very beautifully designed featuring a duel shower head system ( the first of which I had ever seen). There was a lever in the shower to control hot and cold and another valve to control water temperature above 100 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature gage didn't work and for the most part we took lukewarm showers. We already complained enough that to do so would have just resulted in us having to tell the staff about it and that had already proven to just be an addition to our inconveniences. The room service offers very simple fare at exorbetant prices with all types of little costs here and there to expand the company's profit margin. The room service orders took forever and once they arrived my wife's of course was incorrect. We had previously explained that my wife was allergic to tomatoes, and the salad she had ordered was covered in them. We called down to have them correct the order. After two phone calls explaining what we needed, the guy finally arrived 45 minutes later. (What we wanted was just a replacement salad without tomatoes). Instead, he arrived with another sandwich (my order) and a replacement salad for my wife. Of course it was completely wrong again, instead of a the dinner salad she ordered it was a smaller side salad. The meal was comped at our suggestion and left in an incorrect status. The next morning we awoke to find our paper missing. All other doors had a paper in front of them except ours. When we asked the a local cleaning lady what the deal was, she said it happens all the time and told us to simply steal someone else's from there room. Very rock and roll! I don't really care for the whole novelty angle of modern American dining and hotel stay that has become so prevalent in that part of the market these days. I didn't like the whole "how may we rock your world" slogan everyone used whenever you called when they seemed to care so little about what it was that you needed in the first place. It may have been if they actually seemed to care about rocking our world. The check out of the hotel was interesting to say the least. The receptionist asked me how my stay was and I blurted out "terrible" Her jaw dropped as if I had no right to answer with anything other than an affirmative "terrific". She demanded I give her my phone number and tell me what went wrong so that she could pass it on to her manager. When the manager finally got around to calling me the next day she left a confused message saying that one of her staff left her a message telling her to call us. She was clearly not read in on the list of problems I left the receptionist nor was she calling to address those issues. She was merely calling to find out what I wanted. We didn't return her call and resolved that the entire staff at the hotel was simply incompetent. We stayed with friends in the other rooms who were equally unimpressed with their stays at the hotel. Our overall rating was terribly unimpressive and I was really glad we lucked out with a discounted rate prior to checking in the hotel. If you simply want a nice hotel with a polite staff that will do what you need done the first time at a reasonable price avoid the Hard Rock like the plague. If you are just going for the novelty, then bring along some patience for the incompetent staff.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic !! Awesome !! Loved the Hard Rock”
Reviews.Author: Dave5207
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Hard Rock San Diego in January 2008 to attend the Buick Invitational Golf Tournament at Torrey Pines. What an awesome hotel !! The location was great, centrally located in the Gaslamp District. The staff was phenomenal exceeding not only my expectations but my business customers as well. This stay was certainly a welcomed visit, unlike the boring status quo visits with most other large hotels. The rooms were very clean and modern with a sensational shower experience. The beds are comfortable and the room environment was "rockin'". As I checked in, the hotel has the room playing Classic Rock as I indicated my choice in music...nice touch !! You will have to eat at Mary Jane's for breakfast and NoBu for dinner..it was fantastic !! You will love your stay at the Hard Rock !!

Reviews.Title: “did not enjoy our stay”
Reviews.Author: SD_VRSCDX
Reviews.Content: My fiance and i liked the modern look of this new trendy hotel in san diego. Since we live downtown San Diego, we thought we would give it a shot one weekend to have some fun. We are late 20's/ early 30's and we love to party - but good god this was not good! Its a mad house trying to get in the door near the hotel bar sweetwater - even as a guest. The Front doors are roped off to the hotel. THe staff at the bar sucks! the GM at the bar is an [--] - enough about the sweetwater... The rooms are nice- we stayed in the woodstock suite. HOWEVER, we didnt realize it was going to sound like our college days of living in the frat house! Music playing all night long. Coked out people stumbling around the halls and elevators. The staff is non responsive (except for a very nice couple that is soon to be married). We called for a bell boy and never saw one. We carried our stuff down and the concierge person was playing solitaire on the computer. The people at the hotel think its a plush vegas hotel and try to treat the guests like they are on sunset - in other words- they treat people like crap. We are never going back. We'll stick w/ the Ivy for a fun trendy hotel in SD.

Reviews.Title: “Rude, Unprofessional, and Condescending”
Reviews.Author: WorldSurfer11
Reviews.Content: This hotel stay ruined my vacation to San Diego. We made our reservations for our stay on the Hard Rock Hotel website and when we arrived the room provided to us was a far cheaper than we payed for. When we tried to explain this misunderstanding to the hotel staff we were promised a call from the hotel manager that we never received. When we went down to the front desk for the second time asking to speak to the manager directly he then continued to blame the error on us saying we selected the wrong option on the website and the option that we choose did not exist. When we showed him the website that proved him wrong he refused to give us a discounted rate or move us into the room we requested. The hotel also closes its only pool at 6 o clock and the area becomes a noisy night club. The hotel's staffs incompetences continued even after our stay calling us and accusing us of taking all the drinks in the mini bar and trying to add 232 dollars to our bill. Avoid this hotel, this was without a doubt the worst service I have ever received at a hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Tijuana Rolex”
Reviews.Author: Holbywan
Reviews.Content: Well, why the name Tijuana Rolex? It sums up the Hard Rock San Diego experience perfectly. Upon first glance, the Hard Rock hotel is nothing short of spectacular. Flashy lights, impressive amounts of courteous staff and the rooms are new and modern although otherwise average. After you dig in a bit you find out just how unimpressive the hotel is. The staff couldn’t accommodate a large party of professionals largely due to the fact the bars and restaurants in the hotel are managed by someone other than the Hard Rock! Why? Good question but we were not even allowed into the bars after spending $500 per night on a room there. Go figure. The security staff makes you feel like you’re in a maximum security prison. So just that Rolex you bought south of the boarder and were so impressed with, as soon as you get it home you realize just how below average it really is. Good luck!

Reviews.Title: “Not Entirely Impressed”
Reviews.Author: LisaLoves2Travel
Reviews.Content: Online, the hotel rates were $249/night for a studio room. We found a rate of $159/night on Orbitz but wanted to be sure we could cancel so we called the hotel directly. We talked to reservations and indicated the Orbitz rate, which they immediately honored for our stay. A few things to consider: (1) There is a $15 per night charge that is non-negotiable (and not easily found) which covers a 24-hour fitness (not on property), internet access, 2 small bottles of water which they bring at turndown service and a CD compilation of songs you've never heard of. (2) There are 12 floors in this hotel. We had a group of 17 people spanning 9 rooms on 5 different floors. No matter what floor you are on, your floor, bed and barware will vibrate from the dance-club on the first floor (Sweetwater's). We happened to be on the 4th floor, which also has another club on it, and all the way until 2 am we could sing along to the songs 4 floors below like we were there ourselves. After calling the front desk, there were not any rooms available to move to and earplugs could be purchased in the Hard Rock Store. The location is fabulous as it sits on the south end of the Gaslamp District and the restaurants are good, friendly staff, but we will NEVER stay in the hotel again, although we may eat at Nobu. If you don't plan on partying with the younger crowd (we are all in our mid-30's and a fun group), sleep somewhere else. THe folks who are partying until 2 will then get lost finding their room and create a ruckus down the hallway.

HotelInfo.Name: Hard Rock Hotel San Diego
HotelInfo.Address: 207 5th Avenue, San Diego, CA 92101
